body:
Is this the case for all font sizes for you? Looks like it might be an off-by-one.

Do you have any glpyh/font offsets setup? There shouldn't be any gapps between the lines.

Ah, the font size. No, for some sizes it's a perfect curve, there aren't many of those sizes, though. Either way, my comfortable size is 21 at the moment.

I use both offsets, yes. The gaps will have to stay for me, for now. This is already recorded in another issue: #5809
So does the patch fix this for you then? I'd assume the problem is due to offsets. Does it work properly without offsets?
If by patch you mean disabling all offsets, no it did not. Setting a more scale-friendly font-size (16) didn't help either. The curves look exactly like before.
I'm not sure how to go about testing it while the PR is still open. I can say when it's merged to master.
Clone kchibisov's Alacritty, checkout branch, compile?

issue.title: Use cell width to compute builtin font thickness
issue.body:
While using underline thickness could sound logical to draw other
lines most fonts don't make underlines thick compared to cell bounding
box if you increase font size. So instead we're using cell width to
scale builtin font nicely.

This commit also adjusts arcs drawing and alignment.

Fixes #5826.
Fixes #5821.

--
I think it should be the last one in series of fix builtin font.

body: @h0adp0re try using  #5832. It should fix arcs alignment.

I'm afraid I don't have the time to delve into compiling rust programs at the moment. I thought I could install the master branch via `brew install alacritty --HEAD` but it doesn't seem to work so I'll just leave the testing until it's released. Edit: Alright, sorry for being difficult. I found the correct instructions and sucked it up. The build was seamless. Alas, the curves are still not quite there. The thickness seems to be better now but the curves are still oblong/elliptical. For reference, here's how the glyphs bundled with my font (SauceCodePro Nerd Font Mono) look like:

issue.title: Powerline symbols is looking wrong with font: offset: y: 5
issue.body:
When I put this in `alacritty.yml`:

```yaml
font:
  offset:
    y: 5
```

The powerline symbols are looking wrong:

![Screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54639968/151672537-e6a39084-6c49-480b-86ee-25b111dcb281.png)

But in another terminals like kitty, are looking correctly:

![Screenshot from 2022-01-29 14-07-03](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54639968/151672564-51e21cd4-ad7b-4201-92f3-9fea02e99790.png)

Please help me

### Config

```yaml
colors:
  bright:
    black: '#414868'
    blue: '#7aa2f7'
    cyan: '#7dcfff'
    green: '#9ece6a'
    magenta: '#bb9af7'
    red: '#f7768e'
    white: '#c0caf5'
    yellow: '#e0af68'
  cursor:
    cursor: '#7aa2f7'
    text: '#c0caf5'
  indexed_colors:
  - color: '#ff9e64'
    index: 16
  - color: '#db4b4b'
    index: 17
  normal:
    black: '#15161E'
    blue: '#7aa2f7'
    cyan: '#7dcfff'
    green: '#9ece6a'
    magenta: '#bb9af7'
    red: '#f7768e'
    white: '#a9b1d6'
    yellow: '#e0af68'
  primary:
    background: '#1a1b26'
    foreground: '#c0caf5'
cursor:
  style:
    shape: Beam
env:
  TERM: xterm-256color
font:
  bold:
    family: JetBrains Mono ExtraBold Nerd Font
  italic:
    family: JetBrains Mono Medium Nerd Font
  normal:
    family: JetBrains Mono Medium Nerd Font
  size: 14.0
  offset:
    y: 5
window:
  padding:
    x: 2
    y: 2
```

### System

OS: Linux
Version: alacritty 0.10.0 (8a26dee0)
X11
Compositor: picom
WM: bspwm

body: Looks like the built-in font both lacks anti-aliasing and is offset on the X axis by one pixel?

> Looks like the built-in font both lacks anti-aliasing and is offset on the X axis by one pixel?

Yes, and yes.

Depending on the font size, the offset issue can sometimes be inward, other times outward as seen by these two images where the only change increase in font size:

![First](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11382509/151690802-505d1f27-092f-4023-810d-11c284930126.png)

![Second](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11382509/151690803-7f61c036-9ef8-487b-a052-9d159db8bfd1.png)

If anti-aliasing is possible, that would definitely be nice for curvy bends.
